BE

In spite of being in investment phase for nearly ten years.

BE

Quick bit from a recent Deutsche note.

BE

If a market does not hit profitability targets the alternatives for Just Eat are acquiring or merging with number two players in the market, selling or closing the business. For example in India, Just Eat entered the market acquiring a majority stake in HungryZone in 2011 but competitive market position led to its sale to market leader Foodpanda in February 2015.
At the moment, the only market where Just Eat is not the market leader is Benelux. Takeaway.com is the bigger player in Belgium and Netherlands, where it launched in 2000. History shows that number two players can reach breakeven at best. This is not only Just Eat’s CEO view “it's still a truth in the industry that only a number-two player at best has got to break even” but also Takeaway.com’s CEO in an interview said that he is “hesitant to go to other countries” because it would be difficult to displace the incumbents. Being Benelux a key market for Takeaway.com we think that Just Eat will not be able to consolidate and therefore at some point will sell and maybe retain a stake in the new merged entity.

11:14 am
BE

The "winner takes all" idea is reflected in the price, of course, which is rubbish.

BE

Deal EV of €22.5M, which represents c5.3x Sales (based of 1H annualised, well below group multiple of 9.4x 2016 EV/Rev. Not a big deal but now the bulls can say #1 in all top 12 markets – FOR NOW.

11:16 am
BE

Which is it, isn't it? You're worth loads (theoretically) if you're #1 and nothing if you're #2. Levine was very good yesterday on that theme with regards Uber's takeover of that Chinese thing.

BE

"Getting to profitability is the only way to build a sustainable business that can best serve Chinese riders, drivers and cities over the long term," writes Uber's Travis Kalanick, which is ... probably true? Like, a system with two competitors, each of which loses billions of dollars, is not going to serve riders or drivers well over the long term. A system with one profitable incumbent is also perhaps not ideal? I feel like most industries end up in some other equilibrium. (Like: three profitable competitors?) Not, like, subways, though. Public transportation systems tend to be monopolies. I don't know what that tells you about Uber/Didi.

BE

Here's one of those UBS Q&A's I like and you don't.

BE

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?

A: H2 operating profit (continuing) fell 4% to £323m mainly due to lower realised gains than the high level last year. This is a strong result and some 23% above consensus reflecting a lower combined ratio (89.6% versus consensus on 93%) due to a high level of reserve releases (16pts) in home as well as motor. These were from 2014 and prior underwriting years, with some deterioration on the booked 2015. Solvency II capital of 199% at H1 is well above the target range 140-180% and so the group is paying a 10p special dividend (vs cons 6p), resetting to 184% post dividend. The attritional loss ratio improved by 60bps y-o-y.

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?

A: Some modest signs of a return to growth in motor (Q2 own brand motor policies up 1.5% q/q and 3% y/y). Even though releases were high, the improvement in the attritional loss ratio is encouraging. Motor rates were up 9% again in Q2 and although the comps get harder as the year progresses, this is probably slightly ahead of current claims inflation (approx. 5% for DLG) implying some margin improvement.

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?

A: The lower end of the full year combined ratio target of 93-95% assuming normal weather is now expected. On the target basis, DLG's H1 COR was 91.4% so the guidance is still pretty cautious for H2 implying around 95%. Special dividends will now only be considered alongside full year results. Investment yield guidance for 2017 has been reduced from 2.6% to 2.4%, and no further gains are expected in H2. No update on costs (still slightly lower in 2016 y-o-y).

Q: How would we expect investors to react?

A: A 20% PBT beat, an interim special well ahead of expectations, strong capital position, improved outlook, should be taken well, albeit the shares are not cheap on 1.9x 2016E TNAV (top end of its historical range).

11:26 am
BE

And Barclays too.

BE

DLG reported a strong set of results, with premiums in line, but underlying operating profit, underlying combined ratio (COR), reserve releases and dividends all ahead of consensus. DLG has been the worst performing motor insurer year to date (-11%), underperforming Admiral (+32%), Hastings (+12%) and esure (+5%). While DLG’s results bode well for its peers, the results could help Direct Line close its underperformance vs peers.

Premiums of £1.6bn were in line with consensus and our estimates. Pricing remained strong in motor (Q216 +9.5% Q116 +9.4%), while the pressure eased in home (Q216 -0.3%, Q116 -2.3%). Policies in force declined 3%, with motor increasing (+2.5%), offset by a decline in home (-1.4%) and a notable decline in rescue (-9.0%). The main driver of earnings was the improvement in the loss ratio. The underlying (attritional) loss ratio improved 60bps YoY to 68.5%, largely driven by motor pricing coming through. Reserve releases were also much higher than expected, at 15.1% for the group, versus our expectations and consensus of c11-12%. Reserve releases from the motor book stayed at a healthy 20%, largely driven by 2014 accident year. We expect reserve releases to moderate over time, particularly as the older years fully develop and the more recent years have a different (less conservative) reserving methodology. DLG reiterated its full year COR of 93 to 95%, albeit at the lower end of the range if current trends continue.

Total interim dividend of 14.9p was 37% above consensus of 10.9p largely driven by the 10p special dividend vs consensus of 6p and our estimate of 5.2p. Solvency 2 position remains strong at 184% coverage ratio post dividends, ahead of its working range of 140 to 180%.

She's hired a PR as well

PM

Hi Paul,

Theranos CEO Elizabeth Holmes presented its research and development technologies today at the American Association for Clinical Chemistry (AACC).

At this breakthrough presentation, “The Miniaturization of Laboratory Testing,” Holmes discussed Theranos test methods and comparison studies, the innovative Theranos miniLab and results of its Zika nucleic acid-amplification-based assay.

Additional details are provided in the press release below. I will give you a call shortly, but in the interim, should you have questions please contact pr@theranos.com or email me.

Thank you,

Amy Rosenberg
Hill + Knowlton Strategies

PM

PHILADELPHIA— Aug. 1, 2016 — Theranos, Inc. today presented its research in developing novel technologies for the collection and processing of small-volume venous and capillary blood samples on a compact, fully integrated and automated diagnostic testing platform.

11:36 am
PM

Among the highlights of the presentation:

The Theranos miniLab: The miniLab consists of a multi-channel material-handling robot that can dynamically perform tasks on samples that may traditionally require manual processing.

To work with the robot, Theranos devised a disposable cartridge that houses reagents, liquid handling tips, reaction cuvettes, and other consumables designed to facilitate a broad range of tests using different methodologies inside the miniLab.

The Theranos Virtual Analyzer (TVA) is designed to facilitate two-way communication with the miniLab, allowing for control of processes and interpretation of results, all remotely. These results could then be interpreted in a central laboratory.

The company presented 16 studies on miniLab performance data across a sampling of testing categories and methods, including chemistry, immunochemistry, hematology and molecular biology. These studies were conducted under an IRB‐approved protocol.

PM

Zika assay run on miniLab: Theranos released results on the nucleic acid detection capabilities of the miniLab, and discussed its Zika nucleic acid-amplification-based assay.

The company collected finger- stick samples from subjects, including in the Dominican Republic, and shipped those to Palo Alto to run on the miniLab.

The company has submitted assay validation data for this Zika assay to the FDA for an Emergency Use Authorization. The company is unaware of any currently available capillary test for the Zika virus.

PM

test for Zika!?!?!

11:36 am
PM

Capillary collection methods: Holmes described the company’s approach to standardizing capillary collection, including sample site preparation, finger-stick techniques, lancet selection and arterialization of capillary blood.

To facilitate collection, Theranos invented a single‐use sampling device, which is a circuit consisting of two discrete capillary channels coated with anti‐coagulants, and integrated, removable Nanotainer™ tubes that include 2D barcodes associated with patient information.

PM

CEO Elizabeth Holmes gave a very different presentation than expected.
Elizabeth Holmes, CEO of embattled blood testing company Theranos, had promised to share information about her controversial diagnostics technology during a highly anticipated appearance at a medical conference on Monday. Instead, she went in an entirely different direction.

Rather than address the many regulatory and accuracy concerns about Theranos’ Edison blood testing machine, Holmes pitched a new technology called the “miniLab” at the American Association for Clinical Chemistry (AACC) convention in Philadelphia on Monday. The device, which the company says will be able to perform blood diagnostics remotely, isn’t yet available and hasn’t been cleared by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

BE

11:45 am
BE

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has this morning announced that it believes plans to impose a deadline for Payment Protection Insurance (PPI) claims, as put forward in its November 2015 consultation document, should be taken forward subject to an extended consultation running to 11th October 2016. If implemented, the proposed deadline is expected to be June 2019 which is later than anticipated and may therefore require banks to set aside further provisions. For example, in its 2015 full year results, Lloyds^ (LLOY, Buy at 53p) set aside additional provisions to cover claims until mid-2018, so it is possible that an extra year’s worth of provisioning may now be required. Other banks are likely to have applied a similar assumption, in our view. Whether additional provisions are required and how material these may be is uncertain at this stage and we await further comment from the companies in this respect. However, we would not be surprised to see top-ups of a few hundred million pounds (and perhaps as high as £1bn) for each of the large UK banks, with Lloyds being the worst affected.

BE

In terms of the stress tests .... well, I'm not sure whether there's much left to say there. A test without a fail rate is a funny sort of test in the first place.

Here's some grey

11:52 am
PM

Full-year production guidance maintained, improved market conditions should positively impact H2 2016 revenues. Compared to the equivalent periods of 2015, Kenmare’s Q2 and H1 2016 results looked good… but it must be remembered that the 2015 results were pretty dire as a result of power outages and “unofficial” industrial action, amongst other things, so such comparisons are neither here nor there, in our opinion.

For us, therefore, what was more important is that Kenmare is maintaining its 2016 production guidance of 950kt ilmenite (±10%). H1 2016 saw 403.9kt produced, but the company is expecting better in H2 2016 due to increases in dry mining, grade and operating time. Importantly, power quality and reliability have been stable since additional transmission capacity was added by the state-owned electricity company EdM in December 2015, and EdM also installed 100MW of additional (ship-based) mobile power generation in April 2016. According to Kenmare, power “should no longer be a fundamental constraint”.

PM

Cost-wise, Kenmare said in June 2016, that cost guidance remained unchanged. On the markets front, the company echoed its peers in reporting that it is enjoying higher prices, which should be reflected in H2 2016 revenues. The improved pricing was attributed to “a combination of improved offtake from the pigment sector”, “continued decline” of ilmenite supply from a number of countries and “excess inventories” having “declined significantly”. China port inventories at the end of Q2 2016 were the lowest in three years, c.50% down from March 2015 peak levels.

The picture wasn’t entirely rosy, however. In the zircon market, Kenmare experienced further price weakness “due to competitive positioning for sales amongst producers”. The company is hopeful that a recent price increase announced by a major zircon producer “will reverse the downward price trend” and “help to provide some stability”.

Kenmare had cash of US$12.3m at the end of H1 2016 (December 2015: US$14.4m). Financial results for the period are due to be released on August 24th, 2016.

PM

That's from Yuen Low

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 843.30, down 5.5 (-0.65%), High: 850.70, Low: 821.70, Volume: 3.00m
BE

Canaccord this time. Moves to buy from sell. Might've just missed the turning point, I suggest.

11:55 am
BE

1H16 EBITDA beat moves our profit forecast forward a full year

Previous to Anglo American (AAL) reporting 1H16 financials last week, we had forecast US$5bn of EBITDA for 2017. We now forecast ~US$5bn of EBITDA for 2016, a full year in advance and up 23% from our previous forecasts. The strong increase in earnings is driven by the EBITDA beat at the 1H16 stage where AAL reported US$2.45bn vs our US$2.04bn estimate. DeBeers, Copper and Iron Ore all beat on a divisional basis.

BE

DeBeers is the main driver behind our upgrades

DeBeers reported the largest divisional EBITDA beat of US$171mn while delivering US$766mn of EBITDA for the half year. While FX played its part in offsetting significant price falls in the period, volume increases and cost reduction also contributed US$123mn of gains. DeBeers also contributed ~US$500mn to the group's 1H16 working cap inflows by destocking the inventory built up in the division over 2H15. Iron ore and Coal EBITDA increases also help to lift our 2016 and 2017 forecasts.

BE

Capex/OCF low for this stage of the cycle

The ~US$400mn EBITDA beat drove an operating cash flow beat of a similar amount for 1H16. Working cap inflows of US$0.5bn during the period helped to offset the negative tax impact. Capex for the period was just US$1.1bn (vs CG at US$1.5bn), resulting in a Capex/OCF ratio of just 43% in 1H16 - impressive this early in a recovery cycle.

11:55 am
BE

Medium-term net debt target within reach, no further asset sale targets needed

Net debt of US$11.7bn was 2-3% below our forecast of US$12bn, but when adjusted for the US$1.5bn of asset sales already announced, adjusted net debt for the period could be as low as US$10.2bn. Not only should AAL hit its year-end net debt target, but we believe it could also hit its medium-term target of US$6bn in the next 18 months. Given this sort of cash flow strength, we see no need to announce a 2017 asset sale target.

BE

Valuation uplift driven by EBITDA increase and debt reduction

We have increased our target price on AAL to 980p/sh, up 58% from our previous 620p target (average of our NPV analysis, EV/EBITDA, and forward rolling PE). Almost all of that increase is driven by two items: the EBITDA increase (74% of the uplift) and the roll forward of debt reduction (22% of the uplift). On our revised forecasts, AAL's three core divisions now account for 62% of group EBITDA within three years (2018).

BE

Upgrade to BUY rating

We would usually be hesitant to upgrade any stock after such a strong run, but our revised target price points to an additional 15% upside in the stock. Even our lower end valuation on AAL of 823p/share at US$2/lb copper demonstrates valuation support not far below current trading levels. We estimate AAL to now have the same 14-15% potential upside as Glencore (GLEN-LSE | Buy, 215p TP), with a similarly inexpensive 2017 EV/EBITDA mulitple of ~4.5x and the potential for up to a 4% dividend yield by next year. We upgrade our rating on AAL to Buy (from Sell).

11:56 am
BE

So, for the sake of a second opinion, I checked with a PHD graduate of UCL's school of neuro-ophthalmology.

BE

Gist was that integrin αvβ3 looks a lot more attractive a target than the current VEGF inhibitors because there's some promising evidence it can block interactions by increasing the permeability of vessels, effectively helping immune cells stick to non-immune cells.

BE

Topical drops for treating AMD have been problematic and if the delivery mechanism can be strong enough to have an impact on retinal cells without damaging the cornea, that'd be a significant move in the right direction.

12:05 pm
